reviewText: Being a police officer in south central Los Angeles is a scary thing. At least it is in David Ayer's End of Watch, a movie so well made and shot in a semi-documentary style, that some have viewers have mistaken for "found footage" , that you never question it even when the violence reaches extreme proportions.It feels real there for in the mind's eye it is. An unflinching and edgy portal of  big city police life. At times it's a heroic look at police work, at others it is a violent thriller and a dark and depressing look at the daily evil hidden behind locked doors, at times it even feels like a horror story.With a bald and buffed bad ass Jake Gyllenhaal and the excellent character actor Michael Pena giving the performances of their respected careers, at least up to this point. Starring as two dedicated LAPD patrol men. They are best friends, brothers they say, they believe in the service that they offer to those in need.  They don't aim to be heroes, even after a heroic deed, they still say they do not feel like heroes. They are just average realistically portrayed guys.They find themselves in over there heads in the three major food groups: "drugs, money and guns". Just reinstated after a justified on-duty shooting, these "ghetto gunfighters" prove to be a more than a little reckless when they begin an unauthorized investigation that leads to Mexican drug cartels operating in L.A.End of Watch recalls the late Dennis Hopper's great, but largely forgotten Colors, which starred Robert Duvall and Sean Penn. Colors was to cop movies in the `80's what Platoon was to war films.So much of End of Watch depends on it's two leads, and fortunately they deliver. Gyllenhaal and Pena are two of our best actors working today, here you will see a different side of Gyllenhaal and a star making turn by Pena. They camaraderie and friendly banter make these characters seem more flesh and blood than in most movies.Written and directed by David Ayers, who's well known for his screenplays for movies like Training Day and, uh, the original Fast and the Furious movie. He has also directed two prior films, the reasonable Christian Bale-Freddy Rodriguez thriller Harsh Times and the dismal and dire Keanu Reeves and Chris Evan starrer Street Kings. Up to know Ayers has appeared to be somewhat overrated, even Training Day peters out in a terrible and obvious third act. But here with End of Watch Ayers really finds his niche and proves for once to be a first rate filmmaker, perhaps one coming into his own.This is also a change of direction for Ayers. Not an obvious one, at least not on first inspection, but it most certainly is. Instead of corruption in the department, he has good guys here, the new direction is a good one for him. Ayers seems fascinated by cops, LAPD ones precisely, but has never had the nerve to celebrate them before, he feels comfortable in doing so.I think a lot of people will be surprise by just how funny the sharply observed dialogue is, as two punctuate the grim realities in the film. A down and dirty gritty film for sure, but the amiable lead performances make it one of the most enjoyable.End of Watch doesn't offer much new and like a lot off movies these days it relies to much on shaky cam movements, but it does take us into the heart of darkness that is rarely explored in movies any more, the harsh realities of this world. Like all the best movies, it is more entertaining than you might suspect, and make no mistake this is one of the year's very best.see my reviews at moviezonemagazine.com

Have never had a better idea of the day to day grind of being a police officer, a job where you risk your life every day for total strangers, and at the end of the day still can't leave it behind you. I've felt for a long time that Michael Pena is one of the best actors walking around working today, and this film was total confirmation of that - Jake Gyllenhaal, as well, turning in a performance equally real (the film comes off more like a documentary, it's that real, down to the chemistry of Pena and Gyllenhaal as partners sharing the same squad car). Visceral, full of tension, and so realistic in its depiction of a cop's life as to be unsettling, this is a must-see.

reviewText: One of my fondest memories of early childhood is plopping down in front of the TV at 8 p.m. for my favorite show, Adam 12, with a little pepperoni pizza my dad would pick up from the neighborhood shop.  It was a weekly ritual.  Boys wanted to be cops back then, or firemen, or soldiers.  Men they looked up to.  And Adam 12 was, at the time, considered pretty realistic, or at least cops said it was the most like the bouts of the mundane with spurts of danger that was actual police work.  Any buddy cop show gets measured against it for me.  The issue, of course, is that Adam 12 was a product of its time, meaning that as much as it showed people at their worst, it never quite ground under its own weight in depravity and hopelessness.  At its center was the assurance that the police were doing something meaningful.End of Watch is Adam 12 on heroin, in an alley and being pissed on awake by the next knuckle-dragging lowlife that will brutalize it.  It's one of those movies that traffics in the worst of people and offers no answers nor hope.  The police might as well be zookeepers, or maybe landscapers who just keep coming to mow the lawn because they're paid, knowing full well it will grow back again next week for no other purpose than to keep them employed.  It's jazzed up with the standard macho, smart ass posturing that passes for depth, especially when we're young.  To make it topical and I guess cliched, the white and brown leads (a-series-of-triangles Jake Gyllenhaal and happy-scrappy-sappy Michael Pena) trade racially-tinged barbs with each other, you know, to be edgy but also show they really love each other as comrades in arms.  It uses the shaky cam both to keep the budget low and to give it verisimilitude, `cause we all go through life bobbing around or fliming ourselves.Insight never really appears.  Instead, we get smart ass quips or repackaged homilies about the meaing of life.  Lots of statements that end in "bro" and "dude."  Witness, when one  partner asks the other about how to know if he should marry his girlfirend:"My grandma  . . . was really deep, man.  She's seen it all. Know what I'm saying? . . . Can you live without her?Really?  That's it?  Can you live without her?  That's the best she could come up with after 50 or 60 years on planet Earth?Here's another gem."Janet's pregnant.""WHUUTTTTTTTTTTT?"The problem with End of Watch is that these moments of truth are as deep as anything gets.  It's one of those movies that cloaks its emptiness in poses, stares, and attitude.  No wonder nobody knows nothing.  But they're not afraid to proceed as though they do.Fans of nihlism will tell me I just don't get it.  The lack of a point is the point, like life.  Survival is all there is.  That makes it real.  Yeah?  A bowel movement is real too, but that doesn't mean I want to watch it for 90 minutes.  I expect a little more out of art than I do out of a bowel movement.Critics went nuts about this movie when it came up, so I suppose I had unrealistic expectations.  But, really, Southland does the same thing every week.  So did Colors.  So did Fort Apache, the Bronx.  Even then, I didn't feel stupider and like taking a shower after watching them.  I do give it props though for all the unapologetic product placement - Starbucks, Red Bull, Barbasol shaving cream - good job, boys.  Brand names get tossed around almost as often as the F word.  Almost.

reviewText: As you may have noticed, the reviews of this film (on Amazon UK) are up and down; some praise it to the nines, others think it's a load of huey! Well each to their own I guess. If we all liked the same things, ate the same food, listened to the same music, talked the same and looked the same it would be a colossally boring world hey?I had my preconceptions before I watched the film, but very quickly they dissolved and what I found rather than the usual utterly violent, gritty, angry, tough American cop drama, was a film that although about two police officers working in Los Angeles' very dangerous South Central area, known for violent gangs and big drug dealers and murders and violent crimes by the dozen, is actually a bromance, about two friends on the same 'beat' telling jokes to each other, swearing, laughing, being offensive and making sleazy jokes about their women, you know typical guys everywhere, as they ride around their pitch in LA. What happens, and I won't go over the plot or spoil it for you, is they cross serious players and then the film kicks into another gear as they become marked men. Both lead actors in the movie are very good and watchable and convincing, Jake Gyllenhaal and Michael Pena, who play the cop buddies, and there is an outstanding performance by an actor called Maurice Compte who plays 'Big Evil'; not a guy you'd want to cross in an alley on a light night let alone a dark night!All in all, a very enjoyable, if violent, cop movie with a difference.

reviewText: Written and directed by David Ayer, writer of "Training Day," "End of Watch" chronicles the daily activities of LA police officers Brian Taylor (Jake Gyllenhaal) and Mike Zavala (Michael Peña). Shot in South Central, Los Angeles (where the director grew up as a teenager), the film benefits from the documentary-style realism of the location shooting, but what makes "End of Watch" special is the powerhouse acting from the leads and a strong sense of camaraderie that develops between the characters.The plotline of "End of Watch" looks episodic at first sight, with subplots about Brian's girlfriend Janet (Anna Kendrick) and Mike's pregnant wife Gabby (Natalie Martinez). You may wonder where the entire film is going, but keep watching and you will realize there is one uneasy undercurrent that erupts in the final chapter, presence of a new power (represented by AK-47) that is far more dangerous than the local gangsters.A variety of video sources including a dashboard camera of the police cruiser is used here to present the lives of the officers realistically. The "mocumentary" style that is overused these days is employed effectively, enhancing the gritty touch of the film without disrupting the narrative flow.The film's unique visual style is not for everyone, but "End of Watch" is a fine cop drama worth watching for the strong performances from the leads.

reviewText: *** This review may contain spoilers ***'End of Watch' was written in six days by Writer/Director David Ayer. The story focuses on two LAPD cops, Brian Taylor (Jake Gyallanhaal) and Mike Zavala (Michael Peña), on patrol in their squad car in South Central Los Angeles. Taylor is shooting a film project (not sure why) and both officers wear miniature cameras on their lapels. The idea is to give the narrative a documentary feel. At other times, however, Taylor and Zavala are shot from a third party perspective--one wonders if this is supposed to be shot in a real-life documentary style (in real- time), who is supposed to be filming Taylor and Zavala, independent of Taylor's 'flim project'? Obviously filming the entire story from the two officers' perspectives, just wasn't working and Mr. Ayer was forced to adopt the more traditional third party viewpoint, for a good number of scenes.I assume that what Ayer did here was to take some of the more sensational 'inner city' real-life cop stories and condense them into a more fast-paced narrative. Hence, some of Taylor and Zavala's encounters are quite gripping. I'm thinking particularly of the scenes where they find the two children duct-taped in the closet while the parents waste away in a crack den, another scene where a whole group of human trafficking victims are found as well as the discovery of dismembered corpses, victims of a particularly vicious drug cartel.Not all of the police officers' machinations ring true. When Zavala decides to fight Tre, a Bloods gang member, and afterward refuses to charge him with assault, it's difficult to believe that a police officer, would put himself in harm's way, merely to earn a gang member's respect (the beat down could have resulted in serious injuries for Tre, along with a lawsuit--resulting in Zavala's job being placed in jeopardy).More unlikely is the idea that the drug cartel would go out of their way to target LAPD members on a number of occasions. Recall this happens twice in the film: the first time, one cop is stabbed in the eye and another one is severely beaten in the face. Then there is the film's climax, where the protagonists face the 'end of watch'. I realize that in Mexico, cops are targeted all the time by drug gangs and cartels but I have not heard that many stories about American law enforcement being directly challenged by these out of country lawbreakers. Would it really be in these cartel's best interest to directly target LAPD officers? After all, they're in a business where they don't want to call too much attention to themselves. And by assaulting and even murdering LAPD officers, that would lead to the enmity of an entire department. I realize that the cartel hire the local gang bangers to do their dirty work but such select targeting of LAPD by the cartels would result in vastly increased scrutiny as well as retaliation by law enforcement.'End of Watch' also covers the private lives of Taylor and Zavala. Most of the time, they rib one another but also display passionate displays of loyalty (particularly during the tragic climax). The ribbing gets a little tiresome as there's a little too much of it during the film. I particularly was annoyed by the little flashback that was tacked on after the funeral. Why was it necessary to serve up another scene with the partners once again busting on one another. The crudity of their jokes obviously is designed to show that they are 'ordinary' people but showing that directly following the solemnity of the funeral, diminishes their heroic stature.The 'End of Watch' climax is heart-pounding as the officers are cornered by gang member mercenaries, conscripted by the drug cartel seeking revenge. But the gang members themselves are so over the top, that we can't take them seriously. And the awkward way in which they are taken out, hardly seems realistic at all.'End of Watch' features two excellent performances by Gyallanhaal and Peña. There are also a series of fairly shocking scenes involving what LAPD officers have encountered during their travails while on the 'beat'. I didn't buy everything, particularly the idea that drug cartels would invite trouble by specifically targeting LAPD officers. Still, there's enough here to keep your interest, despite the obvious exaggerations.
summary: LAPD cop saga has moments of both heady and implausible verisimilitude
